title: Should I read my lecture slides first or my textbooks? - Quora

response.answer_text: If your professor is worth their salt, the slides should be your “Go!” square. The point of them is to give you an overview of what your teacher wants you to get out of the source material (i.e. your textbooks). Reading the lecture slides first gets your brain looking for those things—kind of an “I recognized that!” that reinforces your mind’s interest—and will help you focus on the core ideas. Bonus tip: there is a lot of research going around right now about the value of a traditional textbook vs. an ebook (google this for specific studies if you’re curious). The conclusion seems to be that we learn and retain more from the traditional book because we’re taking in the information in multiple ways instead of just one (the smell of the book, the act of turning the pages, the mental ‘picture’ of each page, the actual reading, etc.). If your school doesn’t offer physical copies, try asking that the library carry at least one for “emergencies” (tablets do die), or for “further research material”. Failing that, maybe you’d benefit by picking up a cheap used copy off of Half.com - Textbooks, Books, CDs, Movies, More, alibris.com, or something of the ilk. Wishing you a great time learning! :)

I would recommend reading the appropriate sections of the textbook before even going to the lecture, but not necessarily in any great detail. Spend between half and twice as long as the length of the lecture preparing for it. Don’t read slides until after the relevant lecture. You might get the idea you already know it all, or something similar, if you read them before. Slides are a summary. My Quora-suggested credential for this question is Cambridge uni. I was a rather lazy as a student - still am perhaps - but I did read my textbooks as if they were novels before term started. Not that we had slides, mind, certainly not for mathematics. For CS, lecture notes were typically provided. And I didn’t take notes as a mathmo either, something I would not necessarily recommend for other subjects.
